div.head: Regarding the text
div.p:
Voluntas quippe Dei
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 47, c. 1 (XXX).
, etc., after the postquam Master determined about the divine will in general in this distinction 47 he begins to determine about it in specifics. And this is divided in two parts, for in the first place he shows the efficacy of the divine will, in the second place he posits the conformity of our will to the divine will. The second part begins at the beginning of the last distinction at,
sciendum est
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 48, c. 1 (XXX).
.

The first part is divided into two, for in the first place he shows that all things occur according to the divine will, in the second place he considers a doubt that arises. The second begins at
in his verbis
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 47, c. 1
. And this second part is divided in three, for in the first place he introduces the question, in the second place he offers the solution, in the third place he adds a recapituation of what was said or an epilogue. The second begins at,
verum ut supra
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 47, c. 1 (XXX).
, etc. The third begins at,
ex praedictis
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 47, c. 3 (XXX).
etc. And this is the division of the present distinction in general.

div.head: Question
Whether every possible good whatsoever other than the first goodness can be posited by the uncreated will.
div.p: Whether every possible good whatsoever other than the first goodness can be posited by the uncreated will.

div.head: Principal arguments
div.p: It is argued in the first place that not because, if this were the case, then it would follows that God would be able to make sin. The consequent is false, but the consequence is clear since something is good when that something is true. This is confirmed because every motion or moved thing is good just as being is good, but a sin is a movement of the soul, therefore.

To the second, because then it would follow that the possible would be possible from the divine will effectively. The consequent is false because every thing possible was possible from eternity otherwise sometimes the possible would have been impossible. The consequence is clear because the fact that something possible is possible is true and good, such as that Socrates is able to earn merit and be saved and is able to act well. The confirmation is because, if this were so, then it would follows that God would be able to cause infinite delight to a created mind from a created object. The consequent is false because in this case the mind would be able to come to beatific rest in something less than God, which is contrary to
Augustine
Augustinus, xxx . And the consequences is clear because this seems valid.

In the third principal place, it would follows that the divine will would not be in some mode able to be impeded. The consequent is false because the it would produce any effect necessarily, which should not be said. The consequence is clear because a cause which is not able to be impeded necessarily causes its effect. This is confirmed because
God wishes everyone to be saved I Tim 2:4. , and yet this does not occur, therefore the divine will is able to be impeded and consequently he is not able to put every possible good distinct from himself into being.

In opposition is the text from
Esther 13
the Lord God in your dominion all your things have been posited and there is no one who is able to resist your will
Hester 13:9 . Again, there is what is said by the
Master in this distinction
Lombardus, Sent. I, xxx
.

div.head: Conclusion 1
div.p:
The first conclusion: though the infected human will is able to desire evil or the apparent good under the ratio of an existing thing, nevertheless the perfect divine will is not able to perceive or effect anything unless it is good or from his good willing. The first is proved because someone who knowingly sins against his own conscience sins with a sin that is neither enjoyable nor useful, therefore this part is true. The consequence is valid and the antecedent is apparent from the case of the person who is knowingly jealous against another whom they know he is not able to hurt, and nevertheless envies them and wishes to hurt them. Again someone is able to desire, indeed de facto does to desire, to make that which is not
existing or apparent in herself, therefore. The antecedent is clear from the case of those lying only out of a desire to lie, and this is had in
Canone 22, question 2 XXX , and
III Sentences, in distinction 35
Lombardus, Sent. III, d. 35, xxx
. Again, the obstinate wish evil under the ratio of evil, therefore. The second part in the sense introduced in another question is clear through the
Master, in distinction 46
Lombard, Sent. I, d. 46
. Again, it is clear through
the seventh damned article in the order the young ones , saying that,
God wishes the one sinning to sin, error
xxx . To the same point is
Augustine regarding the words of the Psalm
,
that my mouth may not speak the works of men
Psalmus 16:4
etc., and in many other places. The opposite of this part is held by the
Profound Doctor, in the first book of his primo libro Summa in chapters 33 and 35
Bradwardine, De causa dei, cc. 33 et 34
.
First corollary: just as the divine will is not causally the agent of the evil of guilt, so it is not willing sin or the evil of guilt formally.

Second corollary: just as not everything possible, as possible, is antecedently causally produced by God, so not everything future, as future, was antecedently and pleasingly willed by God. This is clear because everything possible and future was possible and future from eternity. The second part is confirmed because then however it would be future it would be antecedently willed by God in the same way, But, that guilt is, is antecedently future, therefore, that guilt is, is pleasing to God. The form of this argument is good, and the conclusion is false, therefore one of the premises is false. The minor premise is not false, therefore the major premise is false, and consequently the corollary is true.

Third corollary: the created will, antecedently causative and effectively volitional, is the principal cause of any infected defective mind. This is clear because God is not the principal cause, therefor the created will is the principal cause.

From what has been said it is clear that it is both repugnant that God is the doer of sin and that he is the cause of evil or sin, which opposes the mode of speaking of
Armicanam> in the Summa Armenorum
. This is clear through the consequence which is made by the
Master in distinction 38 of book 1 , saying,
if the foreknowledge of God were the cause of evil things, then God would be the doer of evil
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 38, c. 1 (XXX)
, where it is clear that to be the cause of sin is to be the doer of sin.

div.head: Conclusion 2
div.p:
The second conclusion: though the divine will is able to produce something infinite in a certain species and to effect this productively, nevertheless the divine will is not able to make anything possible to exist at the same time. The first part is proved nothing impossible nor false follows from being infinite, therefore God is able to make this being. Consequence is clear through
Augustine, in his Epistola 3 ad Volusianum , where he says,
We say that God is able to do that which we confess we are not able to investigate, for the whole ratio of what is made is in the power of the one making
Augustinus, Epistola 3 Ad Volusianum, xxx
. Again,
12 De civitate Dei, in chapter 18 ,
everything infinite is finite to God
Augustinus, De civitate Dei XII, 19
. The second part is proved because God produces and effects a prohibited positive act with his will, and nevertheless he antecedently prohibits the will from producing this thing, therefore. The third part is proved first because all possible things are nothing second becase God would able to empty his entire productive power, which is false, and third because contradictories would verify at the same time. The consequence is clear because any part of the contradiction is possible.

The first corollary: it does not follow, this person is causing or willing an act prohibited by law, therefore this one is a sinner or is someone sinning or acting against the law. The first part is clear because God is the co-effective cause of a positive prohibited act, and nevertheless God in no mode should be called a sinner or someone acting against the law or against the dictate of reason.

Second corollary:
though that which God prohibits he sometimes in some mode wishes and does, nevertheless he does not wish for any person to do the opposite of what he has commanded or something other than what he has commanded. The first part is clear because he has prohibited the act of hate, and nevertheless he co-effects this with the created will, which he nevertheless previously prohibited from doing this act, as was made clear above. The second part is clear because God does not make anyone sin or act against his law.

Third corollary, just as the same created thing is able to be finite and infinite at the same time, so the same create thing is able to be infinitized or to be come infinite in diverse ways. The first is clear because one created thing is able to be infinite extensively or duratively and yet finite perfectively or intensively. The second part is proved because God is able to infinitize a created thing is a manner different from its current infinity. This is clear in the case of being infinite extensively or intensively.

div.head: Conclusion 3
div.p:
Third conclusion: every intelligible thing truly make-able by some power is able to be put into being by the divine will. This is proved because anything that is truly make-able by a finite power is make-able by an infinite power, therefore by the divine will. The consequence holds this divine will is nothing other than an infinite power. The antecedent is proved since whatever is possible productively through a finite power is possible through power of an infinite power, which by itself is able to do whatever is possible with the other power. This is confirmed by the authority of the
Master, in distinction 45 of book 1 , where he says that,
the will of God is not able to be unfulfilled
Lombardus, Sent., I, d. 45, c. 5 (XXX).
. Again,
Augustine, Enchiridion 3 ,
the omnipotent will of God is never conquered
Augustinus, Enchiridion 3, xxx
.

The first corollary: every imaginable future able to come about the divine will by itself is able to impede. This is clear because he would be able to not wish that any such future or possible future would come to be just as he is able to wish that it will be, in fact there is something that is able not to wish which he is not able to which, like sin, therefore he is able to impede this. The consequence is clear since his own not willing with respect to some future is a sufficiently impeding cause. And the antecedent is clear because any future is proposed to him with equal indifference, as was clear above.

Second corollary: just as it is impossible for something not to happen that God wants to happen, so it is impossible for something to happen when God does not permit it to happen. This is clear through
Augustine Enchiridion, in chapter 104 , saying,
from his omnipotence for good it is easy not to permit that which he does not wish to be and easy to make that which he wishes to be
Augustinus, Enchridion 104
.

Third corollary: though every divine doing is a divine willing, nevertheless not every divine willing is a divine doing. The first part is clear through
Augustinum
XXX
because God does not operate unless through willing. The second part is clear because otherwise the divine willing would make the possible to be impossible, which is false. The consequence is clear since the divine will wishes for the possible to be possible and the impossible to be impossible. From what has been said, the affirmative part of the question is clear.

div.head: Objections
div.p:
Against the
first conclusion , the aforementioned doctor, namely
Bradwardine , argues, as seen above in the first place, that it is true that sin exists but everything true is able to be made by God, therefore.

In the second place, God knows sin and does not impede it, and nevertheless he is able to impede it, therefore he is the cause of sin. The consequence is clear since
one does not lack the scruple of an contrary conscience who manifestly neglects to meet a crime
Innocentius, XXX
, as is said in
the rule of law
Gratian, Decretum I, d. 83, c. 3 (XXX)
.
In the third place, because God is the cause of all our motions, many of which are bad, therefore.

In the fourth place, God is the cause of every good thing, but sine is good, therefore. The major is clear. The minor is proved through
Blessed Augustine, in Enchiridion 26
God judges it is better for there to be evil than for evil not
to be at all .

In the fifth place, God is the cause of every just thing, but sin is of this type, therefore. ergo. The minor is clear through what has been said by
Augustine, Contra Iulianum 45
Augustinus, Contra Iulianum 45
. Again, through
Gregory in his commentary on Ezechiel, in the third homily
Gregiorus Magnus, Super Ezechiel xxx
, where it is had that
one is sin is the cause just penalty of another. Many other reasons were made in the other immediate question.

Contra
secundam
et
conclusionem
, si eius probatio esset bona, sequeretur quod Deus posset facere qualibet
pos
possibile esse. Consequens repugnat. Et patet consequentia a simili quia quodlibet possibile non sequitur aliquod inconveniens nec impossibile.

Secundo, Deus producit adintra secundum gradum maximum activitatis ergo et adextra, et per consequens producit infinita vel non potest producere ipsum. Consequens est falsum quia tunc poneret quodlibet possibile inesse.
Tertio, si Deo omnis infinitas sit finita sequitur quod aliqua sit omnis infinitas finita. Consequens est falsum.
Quarto, quaeritur ubi esset tale infinitum quia, si in loco, sequitur infinitum non esse. Patet cum locus sit ultima superficies corporis continentis.
Quinto, sequeretur quod pars esset aequalis toto et unum infinitum maius alio quae universaliter falsa.
Sexto, sequitur quod Deus possit facere delectationem infinitam et in illa quietare mentem. Consequens est falsum.

Contra
tertiam conclusionem , arguitur primo intelligibile est per
finitam
infinitam finitam
potentiam fieri mala et illa non possunt fieri ad?ma voluntate ergo non quodlibet, etc.
Secundo contra corollaria, voluntas Dei est impedibilis probatur quia non posset impedire necessario ageret adextra, et sic quodlibet producibile produceret.

Tertio, non omne volitum a Deo fit, ergo. Antecedens patet
Ad Thimotheum 7
quia
vult omnes homines salvos fieri
I Thimotheum 2:4
Quarto, Deus mala culpae vult non esse, ergo. Antecedens probatur quia praecipit illa non fieri.

Quinto, stat divinum velle esse velle quod Sortes velit et Sortem posse non velle ponatur, ergo in esse. Et sequitur quod Sortes non libere vult immo nihil vult, et tamen divinum velle est velle quod Sortes velit, ergo divinum velle est impedibile.

div.head: Responsiones
div.p:
Ad primam
respondet
Magister, distinctione 36
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 36, xxx
dicens quod non est dignum solutionem propter quod Bernardin dicit quod indignius soluit.
Secundo, posset dici negando maiorem et si doctores videantur dicere oppositum dicitur quod loquuntur de incomplexis veritatibus.

Tertio, et forte melius potest dici quod in talibus formis semper minor est neganda sumendo verum pro re dicti non pro dicto nec pro signo veri, unde licet haec propositio sit vera Sortes peccat, tamen haec deformitas Sortem peccare nec dicitur nec est verum.
Ad secundam XXX , negatur consequentia quia, licet permittat, tamen non proprie vult ratio permissionis nobis non est nota sed tantum sibi.
Ad tertiam XXX , dicitur quod Augustinus sumit causam large pro illo quod est causa esse sive est causa ut sic et ut causa sic, non autem ut causae sint.

Secundo, dicitur quod loquitur de positivo actu tantum cuius Deus est causa coefficiens tantum cum voluntate
3o

Ad
quintam
et
quartam , dicitur simul quod, si intelligitur quod peccatum in se sit aliquod bonum, hoc est falsum. Si vero intelligitur quod aliquod iustum et bonum vel utile quandoque, sequitur
per accidens ad peccatum sicut est verum. Et tunc, si sic uniformiter sumeretur, maior neganda est quia non omne ad quod sequitur per accidens aliquod iustum vel bonum Deus vult.

Ad primam contra secundam conclusionem
, negatur consequentia. Ad probationem dicitur quod non est simile quia aliqua serentur inconvenientia quae patent in probatione secundae partis eiusdem conclusionis.

Ad secundam , dicitur quod improprie in Deo dicitur summus gradus seu agere secundum ultimum posse sui, tamen sumendo ad bonum sensum, negatur consequentia quia non posse producere infinitum simpliciter adextra non dicit imperfectionem, licet in creatura producere posse tantum et non plus proveniat ex imperfectione.
Ad tertiam , negatur consequentia quia non sequitur omnis pars continui est finita Deo cognita, ergo aliqua pars est omnis pars Deo cognita. Consequentia non valet sic in proposito.
Ad quartam , dicitur quod non implicat infinitam magnem vel multitudinem loco contineri, sed tunc non esset ibi dare ultimam superficiem.
Secundo, posset dici quod Deus simul posset duo corpora ponere et tria, immo infinita quae omnia non plus occuparent de loco quam primum corpus Thomas de Argentina.
Ad quintam , negatur consequentia. Ad probationem dicitur quod tale infinitum secundum quod infinitum non proprie haberet partem.
Secundo, dicitur quod non est inconveniens unum infinitum esse maius alio secundum sic opinantes.
Ad sextum , dico quod quidam concedunt consequens et quod mens tantum delectaretur in illo obiecto creato sicut in Deo, non tamen per hoc beatificaretur Rosetus .
Secundo, dicunt alii quod consequens est verum, dicunt tamen quod adhuc non tantum delectaretur in illo sicut in Deo et per consequens non beatificaretur Climeton.

Tertio, dicit Hugolinus quod tantum delectaretur quantum ad gradum in specie sed non quantum ad perfectionem speciei in genere ita quod quantumcumque delectatio intenderetur respectu boni causati numquam deveniret ad perfectionem delectionis causatae ab obiecto increato et sic numquam quietaretur ultimate in illo creato.

Ad primam
dicitur quod deformitas proprie non dicitur fieri cum nihil sit sed potius est de fieri vel deficere a fieri vel facere.

Ad secundam , negatur antecedens ad probationem dicitur quod causam impedire potest esse dupliciter. Primo modo extrinsece ab alio, secundo intrinsece a se ipso modo ad propositionem dicitur quod causa quae non potest retrahi nec cessare ab agere nec ab alio nec a se necessario agit, sed sic non est de deo quia potest libere ab actum adextra cessare et hoc potest dici improprie et large impedire sed quia impediri magis proprie sonat impedimentum proveniens ab extrinseco, sic dicitur quod Deus nullo modo est impedibilis quia quaecumque vult facit.

Ad tertiam , negatur antecedens de voluntate efficaci loquendo, sed non de voluntate signi, et ad probationem dicitur quod intelligitur sic, id est nullus fit salvatus nisi Deus velit ipsum salvum fieri. Hanc ponit
Augustinus, Enchiridion, circa finem
Augustinus, Enchiridion xxx
et
Magister in littera
Lombardus, xxx .
Secundo, potest dici quod ibi fit distributio pro generibus singulorum non pro singulis generum.

Ad quartam , negatur antecedens de voluntate efficaci quia, si sic vellet illa non esse non fierent, et ad probationem negatur consequentia quia aliquando Deus aliquid vult voluntate signi, quod tamen non vult voluntate
beneplaciti ut patet de immolatione Isaac quam praecepit quae sibi non placuit, sed tantum manifestatio obiective fuit et Abraham in volendo facere praeceptum Deo placuit.

Ad quintam , dicitur quod stat Deum velle voluntate signi seu praecepti Sortem mereri et cum hoc Sortem non mereri sed non stat Deum velle efficaciter Sortem mereri et quod Sortes non mereatur et si obicitur ex hoc sequitur quod Sortes non libere meretur quia posito quod deus hoc vellit de facto efficaciter quod Sortes a mereatur, tunc necessario merebitur in a, ergo non libere ergo non libere, et sic non erit meritum quod repugnat dicto posito, ergo.

Hic posset dici quod adhuc Sortes mereri est contingens simpliciter sed ipsum mereri sit consequens necessariam ad Deum velle ipsum efficaciter mereri quia sicut Deum sic efficaciter velle est contingens sic contingenter vult Sortes efficaciter mereri libere ibi, ergo est necessarias consequentiae non consequentis.

div.head: Conclusiones
div.p:
Voluntas quippe Dei
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 47, c. 1 (XXX)
. Prima conclusio:
quod voluntas Dei aeterna quae ipse est semper est efficax et nihil fit contra eam multa, tamen fiunt praeter eam, et haec voluntas
de homine semper impletur quocumque se vertat
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 47, c. 1 (XXX)
.

Secunda conclusio: quod voluntas Dei semper impletur aut a nobis cum bonum et bene facimus aut de nobis cum contra voluntatem Dei facimus quae est signi
et sic de homine semper implet Deus suam voluntatem quia nihil facit homo de quo non operetur Deus quod vult
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 47, c. 1 (XXX)
.

Tertia conclusio: quod Deus quaedam praecepti personaliter in veteri lege et in nova quae ab illis quibus praecepit noluit fieri ut Abrahae immolationem Filii et etiam in evangelio de sanatis ab eo quibus praecepit me cui dicerent, et nota quod illa non volebat simpliciter, sed ad modum volentis se habuit propter aliquam significationem iustam forte ad obiectiam v el humilitatem ostendam et propriam laudem vitandam vel non quaerendam. Et haec sufficiant pro praesenti lectione.
